content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays two separate pieces of tissue, which based on their ovoid shape and surrounding fat, are most likely lymph nodes. Both tissue fragments appear abnormal, showing extensive replacement of the normal lymphoid architecture with irregular, basophilic, and eosinophilic areas. This appearance is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma. My initial impression is that these are two positive lymph nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am examining the larger lymph node on the left. At low power, it is clear that this node is almost entirely replaced by tumor. The area within the green box is one of the distinct tumor nodules. I would zoom into this area to confirm the malignant nature of the cells at high magnification, to assess the specific morphology of the tumor (e.g., glandular, cribriform), and to identify key diagnostic features like nuclear atypia and necrosis. This detailed examination is necessary to definitively classify the node as positive for metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am examining the second lymph node (the one on the lower right). I zoomed into this specific area because it shows a distinct, densely cellular, dark purple (basophilic) focus. This feature, representing a significant architectural abnormality within the lymph node parenchyma, is highly suspicious for a metastatic deposit. I need to examine the cytology at high power to confirm if this is tumor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The high-power view shows a focus of metastatic adenocarcinoma. There are irregularly shaped and fused malignant glands, forming a cribriform architecture. The glands are lined by atypical columnar cells with enlarged, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. A key feature is the presence of intraluminal necrotic debris (so-called "dirty necrosis"). The tumor deposit is surrounded by a dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and desmoplastic stroma, which is the host response within the lymph node. My definitive impression is metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming this is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals metastatic adenocarcinoma. There are poorly formed, malignant glands with nuclear atypia. Critically, there is a large focus of 'dirty necrosis' (comedonecrosis), which is characterized by a central area of eosinophilic, granular necrotic debris and inflammatory cells. The presence of both malignant glands and dirty necrosis unequivocally confirms this is a positive lymph node with metastatic colorectal carcinoma.
